mention.text: the former appeals court judge who was nominated to the Supreme Court by President Reagan but was rejected by the Senate
Robert H. Bork , the former appeals court judge who was nominated to the Supreme Court by President Reagan but was rejected by the Senate
law school professors and other elite groups
Washington over the weekend , Bork -- the target of the first all-out , national political campaign to defeat a Supreme Court nominee --
a constitutional law that lurches suddenly in one direction or the other
the general `` tendency to run law into politics
Legal Theory Now a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute
a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute
The contentious debate over his nomination
an example of what he sees as this country 's increasing
the courts , '' Bork said this weekend , `` but rather the assignment of different functions to different branches of government
the courts , '' Bork said this weekend , ``
a steady erosion of the most basic American right , the right of the people to govern themselves when the Constitution does not say otherwise
the right of the people to govern themselves when the Constitution does not say otherwise
the same bombastic assertiveness that became familiar in the lengthy confirmation hearings
the laws we want to live by
the introduction of the denial that judges are bound by law
his rigidness and his archconservative views
legislators who were elected by the people
The Great Temptation ' Though without its subtitle , `` The Political Seduction of the Law , '' a book called `` The Tempting of America ''
`` The Political Seduction of the Law , '' a book called `` The Tempting of America ''
